sequence:
Émile, the Dancing Angel

<size=45>Chapter 5 - Émile's Romance Theory Pt. 1</size>

scripts.say: Èmile and I were having a chat.
... And because we focus on the details, we can see the beauty of everyday things. A true romanticist values even the smallest of life's beautiful things, wouldn't you agree?
To me, life's small beauties are the things that make a subtle difference. In other words, no matter how small they are, you should be able to find them if you look for them.

The chirping of birds resting on the windowsill; the small flowers growing on the wayside. Once you calm your mind and scan your surroundings, you'll find the world is brimming with those sorts of things.
Émile closed her eyes and gestured like she was hugging something.
The same goes for people. No two people will have the exact same personality. They may have very much in common, but they will undoubtedly differ in some ways.
When you make new acquaintances, it's important to discover what characteristics and traits they have and which set them apart from others.
To find out a person's unique merits, the ones you've never seen before – that's just so wonderfully romantic, you know?
All I need to get through times of great sorrow and pain is remembering that there are still many, many beautiful things I've yet to see.
I want to see those things, I want to experience them, and I want to cherish them with all my heart.
Émile suddenly turned around and faced me, looking a little embarrassed.
Aha... That might've sounded a little pretentious. You may disregard what I just said.
Then Émile made a proposition to me:
I know! How about a date, Commander?
Romance is more easily understood through first-hand experience than through another person's description of it, you know?
Besides, wouldn't you like to have a date with me? *Giggle*
Èmile convinced me to go on a date with her... Which I guess isn't so bad?
